Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation2: A transit authority superviO35r has just entered the cabin for an immediate and unannounced performance audit.
Story: I gripped the subway controls, my eyes flicking between the tracks ahead and the supervisor’s clipboard. He stood stiffly behind me, pen poised, ready to mark down any slip. My heart pounded, not just from the pressure of the audit, but from the text I’d read on my break—my stepdaughter’s hopeful message: “Did you get the Nintendo yet? You promised.” I’d been saving for weeks, pinching every penny, but the rent was due, and overtime wasn’t guaranteed. The supervisor cleared his throat, reminding me to announce the next stop. My voice wavered as I spoke into the mic, thinking of my partner’s worried face and my stepdaughter’s disappointment if I failed to keep my word. The train rumbled on, the supervisor’s eyes sharp, my phone buzzing in my pocket. I felt pulled in two directions—one demanding flawless professionalism, the other begging me not to break a promise that meant the world to a child who was still learning to trust me. The next station loomed, and I had to choose which expectation to meet, knowing I couldn’t satisfy both.
